awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Collective Intelligence for Proactive Autonomous Driving (CI-PAD)
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to develop real-time situational awareness that is shared via vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-network (V2X). The approach is to combine the perception of sensors with interpretation of their situation to enable safer decisions, and take into account the limitations of the communication between vehicles and infrastructure. A highway system that supports autonomous and self-driven vehicles will include infrastructure sensors and onboard vehicle sensors, with massive connectivity among them and distributed intelligence across the entire transportation network. The resulting collective intelligence is one where autonomous vehicles serve as mobile sensors that augment one another along with fixed infrastructure sensors, to construct a real-time picture of traffic. This real-time picture is used to develop proactive driving actions that optimize traffic flow and minimize accident risk. The broader impacts include focused mentoring of undergraduate students who are interested in careers that require graduate training, to broaden participation in the fields of computing and engineering.

The researchers organize an interdisciplinary project in signal processing and machine learning, control and optimization, communication and network science. The collective intelligence framework for proactive driving includes the following modules: 1) Scene Construction, consisting of signal processing and machine learning for constructing a representation of the driving environment from multi-modal multi-view sensors; 2) Situational Interpretation, consisting of driving environment dynamic analysis at progressive levels; 3) Decision Making, consisting of optimization and control to support proactive driving for safety and optimized flow; and 4) A Failsafe Network, consisting of communication and network science that supports optimized traffic flow under nominal conditions of sensing and communication, and moderated flow under conditions of compromised sensing and communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Over the years, to address the ever-increasing burden of our transportation system, efforts have been put into two paths: 1) the improvement of the vehicle’s individual intelligence level; and 2) the enhancement of the transportation infrastructure with intelligence and connectivity. The merge of the two paths could result in leaping advances of both autonomous driving of individual vehicles and the intelligent transportation system overall. However, the current state of the art autonomous vehicles largely operate in an isolated manner. In this project, we aspire to bridge the two paths by establishing a collective intelligence framework that pivots upon the V2V/V2X connectivity. On the one hand, the collective intelligence empowers individual vehicles with beyond-the-vision-range and high-redundancy situational awareness and thus significantly enhanced safety. On the other hand, the autonomous vehicles will be capable of proactive actions that favorably impact the efficiency of the overall transportation systems, even in practical driving environments with mixed vehicle autonomy/connectivity. The research activities in this project address the integration of sensing, data analysis, statistical learning, communications and networking and the physical motion components of autonomous vehicles in a complex dynamic environment, which greatly advances the science of CPS. 

The major outcomes from this project include: 1) the development of a multi-vehicle multi-sensor fusion framework for cooperative sensing in autonomous driving. This framework handles the heterogeneity in sensing data by converting them into a uniform representation and provides spatial information directly which are important for driving tasks. In addition, the uncertainty of the outcomes provided by machine learning based computer vision modules is quantified to guide the multi-vehicle multi-sensor data fusion process; 2) the development of a multi-sensor multi-vehicle cooperative tracking framework for the localization and dynamic tracking task in autonomous driving. The proposed framework utilizes both the traditional sensing devices that are designed for localization tasks such as GPS and IMU and the new sensors that are introduced for autonomous/intelligent vehicles such as LiDAR and camera. The proposed framework is applicable to both the cooperation among autonomous vehicles and the cooperation among vehicles and road side units (RSU). The important issue of malicious cyber attacks is also addressed in this project. In addition, the proposed cooperative tracking framework is also applied to the multicasting scenario, which is a common communication protocol adopted by intelligent transportation systems; 3) the development of online algorithms to characterize the drivers' driving style. Compared with the existing work, our proposed algorithm tries to develop heteorogenous models for drivers with different driving habit, which can assist the autonomous vehicles to understand its surrounding driving environment; 4) the application of statistical learning methods to describe the vehicles into clusters to better understand the driving dynamics. Compared with most traffic monitoring algorithms adopted in intelligent transportation systems, our proposed method tries to cluster the vehiles with similar driving behavior into groups and study the dynamics of the groups as well as how individual vehicles leave and join different groups. 

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2024
Modified by: Dongliang Duan
